newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian lev hits new lows amid political unrest.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian lev hits new lows amid political unrest.

text.p: The Bulgarian lev traded at new lows between 935-950 per dollar around 1030 local time (0830 GMT) from 920-930 at Friday's close due to scarce foreign currency supply and amid ongoing political uncertainty, dealers said.
"Large final clients are bidding for foreign currency this morning, but supply is very low and pressure builds up on the lev," one dealer said.

"There is still no political consensus on formation of a new government, no foreign funding agreements are in sight and there are no signs that a currency board will be introduced soon. How then can the lev be stable?" another dealer said.

Low dollar liquidity from expectations of a further lev fall and relatively high dollar demand from large final clients pressured the lev to 920-930 per dollar on Friday from around 750 last Monday, dealers said.
Thousands of protesters marched through the Bulgarian capital on Sunday to demand a general election, but the ex-communist Socialist party repeated its insistence on forming a new cabinet.

Despite 21 consecutive days of street protests, the Socialists kept to their insistence on forming a broad-based cabinet of technocrats, which President Petar Stoyanov has said is unlikely to win public confidence. -- Anastas Petrov, Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-876032
